channel.title: Oliver Gilan
channel.description: Personal blog and thoughts on technology, engineering, and life

item.title: AI requires resetting the frame
item.description: In a world where intelligence is too cheap to meter, is the generic chat box the final UI? I argue that the best products of this generation will go deeper, and reset the frame entirely on workflows.

item.title: AI Hasn't Helped Most Engineers (yet)
item.description: Most of the productivity gains from AI and other DevTools of the past decade have not made their way to the engineers working on large, mature codebases. If we want to make our biggest companies more productive we need a better system of record for the engineering org.

item.title: The Cloud Hasn't Been Won
item.description: Cloud hosting is one of the biggest markets in the world and it's right there for the taking.

item.title: Visceral Moments
item.description: There are moments in life that are more than just mere memories of events. They are memories of feelings stored in the body itself and they are what makes a life full.

item.title: Authority Must Be Delegated with Responsibility
Full Gluten Tolerance
item.description: In the summer of 2019 I became violently ill and lost the ability to eat gluten. Over the past two years I've slowly gained some tolerance back and I outline my plan herein to regain full tolerance for eating gluten.

item.title: Kidney Crisis
item.description: Nearly a million people in the US suffer from total kidney failure yet only 20,000 kidneys are available for transplant each year. The kidney crisis is only getting worse and needs a revolution to solve it.

item.title: Goals for 2024
item.description: Taking stock of my progress.

item.title: What the NFL Taught Me About Business
item.description: The NFL acts as a microcosm for business and can teach us lessons about building successful organizations from small startups to large companies. Understanding these lessons will shape the choices and effectiveness of both leadership and ICs and can radically alter the outcomes of a business.

item.title: I Moved to San Francisco
item.description: It's time for a new era in my life. I'm now in the arena.

item.title: Changing of the Seasons
item.description: Winter brings with it hard times and dark days but I am remembering what it means to find beauty in every season and what type of life allows me to do that.

item.title: Is Tech Losing Its Leverage?
item.description: Software used to be the highest leverage differentiator between tech companies and the rest. I'm not so sure that's the case anymore.

item.title: Living With Buggy Hardware
item.description: Over the past 3 years I fought for my life against a failing body. Now I'm trying to live with the weakened state I find myself in.

item.title: 6 Questions
item.description: Fenyman had a concept of 12 questions which he contemplated for much of his professional career, constantly adding new facts and insights to each category over time. This allowed him to progress along many axes at once over long time periods until the accumulation of understanding in any given question reached the point where others considered it a breakthrough. Here are the 6 questions I'm thinking about these days.

item.title: Thinking Short and Long
item.description: Thinking short and long is the act of focusing on the day-to-day tasks required to move yourself forward while also zooming out and effectively strategizing against a longer term vision. When building a company you will need to do both effectively but in the trough of sorrow you will need to do both at the same time all while the pressure and problems you face seem to multiply endlessly.

item.title: Believing is the Difference
item.description: The world can feel like a rational and deterministic place completely indifferent to your emotions but that's not always the case. When it comes to competition, learning something new, achieving something ambitious, or even changing who you are your belief can be the difference between winning and losing.

item.title: Just Start
item.description: It doesn't take much to become better than average at anything in life. The most important step is the first. Just show up and start and the rest will follow.

item.title: Software Crisis
item.description: The term software crisis was coined in 1968 to identify the inability of software development to keep up with the rapidly growing usage and requirements of computing. Today the crisis continues with poor software more common than good software and failure more common than success.

item.title: Where No-Code Fails
item.description: No-Code tools like Webflow, Bubble, Adalo, etc. are all the rage these days. Despite this I believe they all have a fundamental problem to overcome: if they are simple enough for non-engineers to use they aren't powerful enough but if they are powerful enough they become too complex and a real engineer will most likely just use code instead.

item.title: Goals for 2023
item.description: 2023 is coming. The big areas of focus for me in this new year will be career, health, adventure, and mind.

item.title: I Was Wrong
item.description: Notes on the rise of AI and large language models.

item.title: My Brain is Single-Threaded
item.description: Your brain can only focus on one thing at a time. Multitasking is just an excercise in context switching and the more important a task the costlier it is to switch contexts.

item.title: Internal Knowledge Systems
item.description: Effective teams consciously engineer how knowledge flows through their organization. For tech teams, building this internal knowledge system requires effective documentation.

item.title: Prioritizing Efforts
item.description: Working on the right thing is as important as working hard but when a startup is rapidly growing how do you determine where to best focus your efforts?

item.title: Is Work-Life Balance Worth It?
item.description: In the debate of work-life balance versus work-life integration it seems as though balance is winning out over passion as more and more people view life as the hours spent between clocking in and clocking out. Why is this viewpoint dominating and does it lead to a fulfilling life?

item.title: How to Create a Blog from Scratch with Hugo
item.description: Hugo is a static site generator built in Golang. Fast compile times and a powerful templating engine makes it a powerful option for creating sites like a blog.
